answers.author: Paul Scher
answers.text:
To anticipate the impact of a federal government shutdown on state and local governments is a tall order since unfortunately I forgot my crystal ball at home (LOL). Moreover it's difficult to predict how the current government would respond to a shutdown, because each federal agency is responsible for crafting and updating its own "shutdown plan.” Without delving too deeply into the complexities of the federal budgetary process, the devolution of Federal programs on to state and local proxies, or the continuing trend of contracting and privatization, it falls on us then to examine the impact of the five-day federal government shutdown of November 1995 and the twenty-one-day federal government shutdown, ending in January 1996. 
The federal fiscal year ended on September 30, 1995. In most years lawmakers passed twelve appropriation bills for the president's approval. Those bills gave federal agencies the legal authority to spend and conduct business. As a resulted of the Republican-controlled House of Representatives’ failure to pass and President Clinton’s failure to sign the FY 1996 federal budget however, Congress was forced to pass a continuing resolution on October 1 to authorize continued funding for departments until new budgets could be approved. This afforded the federal government approximately two weeks to choose between compromise and a shutdown of the federal government. 
What followed was an elaborate game of chicken between then President Clinton and Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich. Because the President refused to make the budget cuts Republicans demanded, Speaker Gingrich threatened to refuse to raise the debt limit, allowing the country to default instead. Both sides refused to budge and thus on November 14, 1995 the federal government discontinued non-essential services. The standoff lasted until November 19. The Clinton administration released documentation of the costs of the shutdown. The shutdown was resolved with the passage of a temporary spending bill, but underlying disagreements between Gingrich and Clinton were not resolved, resulting in a second shutdown that lasted from December 16, 1995 to January 6, 1996.
The most immediate impacts of the federal government shutdowns were that hundreds of thousands of federal employees and government contractors were furloughed. While Federal employees eventually received back pay, contractors didn't get so lucky. Lost wages equals less taxable income, not only on the federal level but on the state and local levels as well. Lost income tax revenue aside, the shutdown proved an inconvenience to citizens, including delays in social security, Medicare, and FHA mortgage loans. Further information about the causes and effects of government shutdowns is available at http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/RL34680.pdf

author: Michele Frisby
text:
Today we received this question from a Governing magazine reporter:
"I’m writing an article about the impact a federal government shutdown could have on state and local governments, since it’s looking more and more like that’s a real possibility. Could you put feelers out in your organization and see if anyone has thoughts? It sounds like it will impact states more than local governments, but I figured I’d ask."
Any thoughts?
title: Impact of Potential Fed Closing on Local Govts.
